text: uh
hi everyone daithenny Liv Tano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of this new hives
album the death of Randy Fitzsimmons
this is the first album in 11 years from
Swedish rock outfit the hives a band
that admittedly I do have kind of a soft
spot for because back in the day I was
really into the early leg of their
discography back when we were having
like that 2000s rough and dirty garage
Rock Revival thing with white stripes
and black keys and the vines and the
kills and The Strokes early Arctic
Monkeys Yeah Yeahs it was a whole era
and the hives had an especially Punky
but also theatrical approach to this
genre which manifested in the
viciousness with which they would play
but also their matching suits and the
weird lore surrounding the band which is
referenced in the title of this new
album because it is said the band formed
under the guidance of a Mr Randy
Fitzsimmons who I guess instructed them
to form as a garage rock band in the 90s
and these types of tall and exaggerated
Tales are nothing new for garage Rock I
mean the strange lips who originally
wrote the hit I want candy were nothing
but a trio of Studio musicians and
producers originally but when they
formed this band they pretended to be
brothers brothers who were also
Australian and grew up on a sheep farm
and they also posed with African drums
and wore zebra print vests on the cover
of the only record they dropped which I
guess was an attempt to play it some
kind of exotic aesthetic it was the 60s
everyone was insane but yeah I guess on
this new hives album Randy Fitzsimmons
is dead and I don't know exactly what
that means for the band it's not
something that they sing about at length
within these songs but I will say maybe
this narrative shift is representative
of a kind of creative freedom for the
the band because while there are plenty
of rock and garage Punk anthems on this
thing to be had that sound like classic
hives there are also quite a few breaks
in character too dramatic moments like
stick up which is a devilish and
brooding cut with these uh very very low
down horn sections whole thing sounds
like the soundtrack to a nasty mobster
movie where everyone ends up sleeping
with the fishes the lyrics kind of
parallel that Vibe as well and
ultimately come to the conclusion that
life ain't nothing but a stick up there
are some good intentions behind this
track and the band is certainly getting
ambitious here that's for sure but I
will say the track does kind of border
on like being theater Kid Rock moving to
the track smoke and mirrors which
dabbles in these really direct old
school Punky grooves and chord changes
the whole thing kind of Vibes like a
Ramone song honestly I feel like the
band had it in them too put a more
interesting spin on this sort of thing
but they just didn't kind of the same
with that's the way the story goes which
I get the band not wanting every song on
this record too sound the same or sound
like one of their older songs but I
don't think the answer to avoiding that
was to basically soak this thing in so
much Reverb that it becomes the most
Washed Out song on the record Another
surprise on the album has to be crashed
into the weekend which is a Clapper it's
a stomper it's borderline a hoot Nanny
with these really raw guitar chords and
what sounds like a super rustic and
folksy acoustic breakdown on the bridge
it's repetitive but it works and again
sees the band getting in touch with
their former selves while doing
something different plus I think
thematically and aesthetically the track
brings back sort of a demonic Mystique
that rock music used to have way back
when the last major surprise on this
record comes in the form of what did I
ever do to you which dabbles in some
drum machine beats and some sequence
synths and this track's probably the
biggest surprise W on the entire record
the beats and bleeps and bloops create a
kind of eerie and the stiff foundation
for the song to sit on meanwhile front
man Helen Pele almquists vocals have
this really robotic chorus effect on
them in one breath the song is getting
very regimented but then in another he's
just seething yelling at the top of his
lungs on the song asking what he did to
deserve the treatment that inspired the
song and these emotional limitations
that are set by the song sounding so
computerized put the whole thing at a
very repetitive tension building simmer
that is until the very end where we get
hit full on with these heavy Rifts and
thick horn sections might just be the
biggest finish of any hype song ever so
those are the more unlikely moments on
this LP uh beyond that there are
actually quite a few songs that show the
hives kind of sticking to their guns and
sounding good doing it which in a way is
surprising considering the different
creative roads their garage Revival
contemporaries have been on since the
early 2000s but here the hives are with
the opening track bogus operandi which
is hitting us with Speedy riffs
infectious choruses and some shouty lead
vocals as well whole thing sounds like
it could have been on their record Veni
Vidi vicious except Maybe This Time
Around the guitar tones were sounding a
bit more blasted out and chunkier like
something off of a Queens of the Stone
Age album and yeah the song kicks ass it
rules we also have the very short
trapdoor solution which has grown on me
since I originally heard it it's very
brief fast Punky demeanor it's Mega
distorted too it sounds like something
from their barely legal album from 1997
then count down to shutdown follows very
much the same formula that bogus
operandi did and gets just as much gold
out of the formula in the process then
on rigor mortis radio the band Embraces
some a very campy old school rock tropes
with some vintage riffs and some hand
claps Pele vocally is acting more on
this track than I think he has on a lot
of the songs I brought up so far really
painting a character portrait of this
powerful egomaniac who is shutting down
the asks needs advances of other people
he's declining offers he's deleting
emails again it's dramatic but also
rocks there are a few other moments
where I think the hives are up to their
old tricks there is two kinds of people
which has a pretty funny hook putting
against each other women and men cops
and police friends and enemies
describing each of these pairs as being
two kinds of trouble there's also the
bomb that um you know is very fast paced
is very in your face but I found the
chorus on this one to be maybe a little
too campy and obnoxious almost heading
in that novelty garage pop Direction
Like My Boyfriend's Back sort of thing
but obviously not as as intentionally
cutesy you know they're kind of hitting
us with these words of you know hey bomb
bombshell bomb we're blowing up tonight
yeah it's it's a little balls to the
wall and hokey in that way but hey you
know if you're looking for a garage rock
song that uh it sounds like the
soundtrack to a wild ass kegger here it
is there's also the very brief step out
of the way which is the closing track
for the entire record uh it is fast and
it is uh very explosive and it's cool to
hear the band kind of playing with this
amount of fire and energy after all
these years but I do think after waiting
for so long for a new album This is a
kind of unceremonious closer but still
overall it is cool to hear the hives
back and uh sounding uh pretty Veni Vidi
vicious at this point in their career
yeah feeling a light to decent seven on
this one
